author: workshopmaybe
title: Plutus Project-Based Learning
description: Keep Gimbalabs PPBL free for aspiring developers.

f6_assessments.q0: The main aim of the project is to provide a completely free 10-week course on Plutus knowledge and Plutus-based dApp design to aspiring developers. This is great, the design course not only provides knowledge but also provides an environment for students to practice through small projects. I totally think the solution fits the key metrics of the challenge - Education for development in the Cardano & Catalyst ecosystem, project development in an open-source framework, and accessible knowledge. The course will bring new career opportunities to the students and a resource of potential developers for the Cardano ecosystem. The author has very well described the course content, outlining the positive impact of the project on the Cardano ecosystem. However, about the form of learning of the course is online or offline, the proposer has not mentioned it yet.
f6_assessments.q1: The author has built a project development plan divided into 3 phases: pilot phase (ongoing), review project quality and feasibility phase, continuing course implementation phase. Right at this point, the viability of the project is still a mystery, the core aim of the proposer is to raise funds for the next iteration of the course and keep it free. Regarding the budget, the author also points out the main resources to support the project implementation and the budget allocated for each resource. For the budget to pay for six-course facilitators, I encourage the author to allocate the budget at an hourly rate, which means the total number of hours worked by these six staff members. I'm not sure about the Canvas on-boarding & annual subscription fee, how many subscriptions will this budget cover? In terms of personnel, they have made effort to gather members with deep knowledge, work experience, working skills in the field of Blockchain and education, which can ensure the project is well run. However, besides describing members' biographies, the proposers should reinforce their description by attaching Linkedin profiles, previous project profiles (if any) of each member.
f6_assessments.q2: Since this is an open-source development project, anyone in the Cardano community can access the GitHub link provided by the proposer to measure the progress and development of the project. However, the author has not provided us with a roadmap including milestones and achievement timelines, it is difficult to imagine and consider how successful the project would be without these specific KPIs, the information provided by the proposer is only conceptual. If possible, the proposer should develop a roadmap that includes the main tasks and KPIs achieved in each month, how many people enroll in the course, what % of applicants complete the course, etc

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal captures the full essence of the challenge. The Plutus PBL group has been helping people learn Plutus while building usefull components, all in a public and open manner. This not only grows the number of developers but also creates connections and collaborations.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team itself has grown naturally from early participants. This in itself shows the capacity of this team to collaborate and deliver. They have shown to be consistent in holding their sessions and have consistently attracted new interest.
The plan itself is straightforward and very realistic, repeating the current format, completing the course in 10 weeks.
f6_assessments.q2:
The metrics provided are simple, yet effective and tie in together well. The main focus is on participation and retention. To track continued value beyond the scope, contribbutions to specific repositories will be tracked. This might miss out some value, but guarentees what is tracked, matters.

Furthermore, the method of work allows for anyone to observe the work and the testimony of the participants adds to the visibility of the efforts.

f6_assessments.q0: I strongly agree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge. The idea here is to make plutus project based learning (PPBL) free and accessible to everyone. The team behind this proposal is from Gimbalabs, a pioneer in Cardano ecosystem, which has already trained a lot of developers on plutus. They focus in this proposal to keep their PPBL course free, which will coexist with PPP program from IOHK. As a developer myself, I agree that project based learning is the best way to get familiar and start contributing to any technical topic. Hands on experience always wins, and this proposal will exactly do that for future developers, making their onboarding to Cardano developer ecosystem faster.
f6_assessments.q1: I agree that this proposal is likely to be implemented. However, I see some gap areas in the proposal writeup. Firstly, the team is well rounded and well experienced. THey have really good experience with respect to training and educating developers/non developers in Cardano eco system. The timelines for delivering the first iteration of 10 weeks course is clear. However, I would have liked to see some further explanations on budget. The terms such as - apprentice facilitators, Canvas on-boarding & annual subscription fee - could have been explained further in details. The risks mentioned are actually my concern too : which is how to make this free model sustainable, which means will for future iterations again this has to be funded OR only a certain percentage of currently asked fund will be asked ? Nevertheless, the team experience and their expertise makes this proposal highly likely to be implemented, but since proposal could have explained few details a little better I will not be able to strongly agree.
f6_assessments.q2: The auditability is quite well explained. The KPIs mention about how many people onboarded and how many % of them completed the course, and how many % of them actually provided good quality of the capstone project. The gitlab links are provided where the course progress can be already seen. This is openly accessibly by the community. Additionally, the roadmap and timeline of 10 weeks first iteration is documented and given the experience of the team and already done progress adds it to the high auditability of this proposal.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposers would build a course to help developers such as myself to learn by doing, which is the best way. I have been a part of a couple of such courses, and I would be happy to take part in the next round, because I'm learning how to be a better participant in the ecosystem. Learning how to build on cardano is no small task, and the fact there are people trying to ease the process makes me optimistic about the outcome. This project would give back a lot to the community so it fits right into the challenge settings and category. The impact from the realization of this proposal would be immense and even though it might have a slow participation start, I'm sure it will grow.
As a developer I'm excited for this and wish good luck to the authors of the proposal. I will vote for this to be funded for sure!
f6_assessments.q1: I was able to verify the listed team members' credentials, but it would have been a lot easier to do so if there were links to their CVs or linkedin profiles instead of just names, so my suggestion for fututre proposals would be to add the links to make the verification process easier. Help your friendly neighbourhood spider.. i mean CA. The budger is prety clear. Basically paying fair salaries to the trainers, relating to the guidelines. There's a realistic timetable to complete the project and I'd say the credibility for this project is really high considering they're already working on it, and the process has been proven to work. The considered challenges are real, but I'll help on the adoption front and participate in this or the next one.
f6_assessments.q2:
The gimbalabs gitlab is linked in the proposal, so auditability is easy to do. The project is open source so anyone can have a look and learn a thing or two. The roadmap is good, the KPIs are suitable as well. The one suggestion I have is to have actual expected numbers so the projects' progress can be measured and goals achieved or optimized and that can't happen without proper expectations or at least estimations.
The description of the problem is relevant and the proposers offer an already working solution. The proposers contribute greatly to the ecoystem and see what the community needs in order to move forward.

f6_assessments.q0:
This great proposal is within the challenge goal, because I think this implementation will be a need for the Cardano developers and it will help many people to increase their participation in developing smart contract and Dapps for Cardano community projects and organization.
The proposal want to improve existing Gimbalabs Plutus learning programs to keep this course free for learners through funding from Project Catalyst challenge.
This proposal is clear and concrete, based on Gimbalabs experience and they are already delivering this project..  This is an important proposal to attract many new users to the Cardano ecosystem for developing many new applications.
The proposal clearly articulates the contest, the problem, the challenge and how it will add value to the Cardano ecosystem and for all of the stakeholders.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer’s team is very well skilled about the whole context (developers, business manager, founder, …), and  they very well knows the Cardano community. There are detailed career profile of the proposer team, but not the links.
The scope of the solution is well explained (e.g. how the funds will be spent, what features will be developed, milestones and so on…).
In my opinion the budget requested is coherent to the challenge (75k$), and coherent with the elapsed.

The proposer provides a detailed step-by-step plan for the learning program development
Overall I think it’s simple to define the complete success of the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2:
Success criteria is simple to identify and trace with key metrics to measure the success (e.g. Number of people enrolled in PPBL Course, % of enrollees who complete the cours,…).
I think that the successes and metrics are qualitative verifiable but that aren’t quantitative KPIs
The proposal offers a  timetable to complete the work. The proposer hasn’t considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful adoption.
The proposer have just founded 2 proposals (Fund1 e Fund2) from Project Catalyst.

f6_assessments.q0: The idea to continually engage in a Plutus Project Based learning program for free is welcomed development and overwhelmingly supported by the community. The proposal aims to train aspiring developers in the ecosystem whilst making the project, an open source by making tools and other activities accessible to other developers in the ecosystem. The proposal fits conveniently with the objectives of this campaign category as it promotes cross collaborations of developers and  provision of tools for other developments in Cardano.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal's team is well known and experienced with required competence to deliver this project. Relevant collaborations were also made to ensure that the proposal is effectively implemented. The budget breakdown and cost analysis which is to incentivize the trainers/facilitators and participants are reasonable and well articulated. The risk factors were clearly noted and solutions proffered. From the information provided and the past achievements of the team and coupled with the fact that the first batch of the program has started , am convinced that the proposal is good hands for an effective implementation.
f6_assessments.q2: From the information provided, the proposal can be reliably assess and monitored to affirm its progress and development. The Success Metrics are relevant and reliable measures to verify the development of the project if eventually funded.

f6_assessments.q0:
The problem statement does not indicate a problem, but the solution presented is relevant to the topic of this challenge.

The creation of a course with open source material to train new developers in Plutus is possible directions for this challenge.

Training more developers is essential for new projects to continue being developed on Cardano.

The metrics defined for this challenge are relevant but it would be important to establish KPIs(with targets) to better assess the impact of the challenge in relation to the number of trained developers and the quality of the courses.
f6_assessments.q1:
This is an ongoing project, the idea is that this proposal can allow the continuity of the course for free (for new students)

The team has members with relevant experience to conduct the courses, team members participated in the Plutus Pioneers Program, have experience with smart contract development and education. I would recommend including sources related to the experiences of team members. A repository with course material has been included.

Regarding the timeline, the course is already underway and its first cohort should end at the end of April, the new stage, referring to this proposal, starts in May and should last 10 weeks.

The budget will be allocated to 5 course facilitators ($1000/week for each), 10 apprentice facilitators ($250/week for each). There is no information on hourly time during the week, which makes it difficult to assess whether the budget allocation is reasonable. The allocation of $14,500 for "Canvas on-boarding & annual subscription fee (to be applied to future iterations of the course)" could be better detailed, there is no information on the duration of subscriptions.
f6_assessments.q2:
Quantitative and qualitative metrics were defined to evaluate the performance of the courses, which helps in the evaluation of success and auditability. I would recommend including KPIs (with targets).

There is a simple timeline, there is no detailed description of milestones throughout the course or references of what material will be covered in each week of the course, this would be positive for evaluating the progress of the course over the weeks.

The course material is open source and will be included in the repository, which increases transparency and the possibility of following the progress of the course and the content used as a reference.

There is no explicit target problem, but it is possible to understand that the problem addressed is the lack of practical material to prepare developers in Plutus. The solution is aligned with the challenge.

solution: 10 Week course where participants learn by doing.
experience: Distributed team of developers and teachers. 6 months experience working as a PPBL team + delivering first iteration of the course right now.
